questions.question: What is a mathematical proposition?
choices: A mathematical proposition is a statement which is both true and false.
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is true
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is false.
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is either true or false.
solutionSteps: Mathematical proposition can have one of two possible truth values (true, false).
Therefore, mathematical proposition is a statement which is either true or false.

questions.question: What is the logical negation operation?
choices: A mathematical proposition is a statement which is both true and false.
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is true.
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is false.
A mathematical proposition is a statement which is either true or false.
solutionSteps: Logical negation operation is a mathematical operation, used to find the opposite truth value of a given proposition.
Result of the logical negation operation is the opposite of the original proposition's truth value.

questions.question: What is a predicate?
choices: A predicate is a statement whose truth values depend on a variable.
A predicate is a statement whose truth values depend on two variables
A predicate is a statement whose truth values depend on three variables.
A predicate is a statement whose truth values depend on one or more variables.
solutionSteps: Truth values of a predicate are not fixed but depend on variables.

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. When is the proposition “$P$ and $Q$” true?
choices: The proposition “$P$ and $Q$” is true when either $P$ or $Q$ are true.
The proposition “$P$ and $Q$” is true when $P$ is true.
The proposition “$P$ and $Q$” is true when $Q$ is true.
The proposition “$P$ and $Q$” is true when both $P$ and $Q$ are true.
solutionSteps: For the "and" operation to be true, both $P$ and $Q$ must be true.

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. When is the proposition “$P$ or $Q$” false?
choices: The proposition “$P$ or $Q$” is false when either $P$ or $Q$ are false.
The proposition “$P$ or $Q$” is false when $P$ is false.
The proposition “$P$ or $Q$” is false when $Q$ is false.
The proposition “$P$ or $Q$” is false when both $P$ and $Q$ are false.
solutionSteps: For the "or" operation to be false, both $P$ and $Q$ must be false.

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. When is the proposition “$P$ implies $Q$” false?
choices: The proposition “$P$ implies $Q$” is false when $P$ is false and $Q$ is true.
The proposition “$P$ implies $Q$” is false when $P$ is false and $Q$ is false.
The proposition “$P$ implies $Q$” is false when $P$ is true and $Q$ is true.
The proposition “$P$ implies $Q$” is false when $P$ is true and $Q$ is false.
solutionSteps: "implies" operation is false when $P$ is true but $Q$ is false.

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. What is the converse of “$P$ implies $Q$”?
choices: The converse of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$P$ implies $Q$”.
The converse of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$P$ is $Q$”.
The converse of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$Q$ is $P$”.
The converse of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$Q$ implies $P$”.
solutionSteps:
Converse of an implication switches the positions of $P and $Q.
Step 2: Converse of "$P$ implies $Q$" is "$Q$ implies $P$"

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. What is the contrapositive of “$P$ implies $Q$”?
choices: The contrapositive of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “not $P$ implies not $Q$”.
The contrapositive of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$Q$ implies $P$”.
The contrapositive of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “$Q$ implies not $P$”.
The contrapositive of “$P$ implies $Q$” is “not $Q$ implies not $P$”.
solutionSteps: Contrapositive is a logical transformation of the original implication.
Step 2: Contrapositive of "$P$ implies $Q$" is "not $Q$ implies not $P$"

questions.question: Let $P$ and $Q$ be propositions. What is the proposition of “$P$ if and only if $Q$” false?
choices: The proposition “$P$ if and only if $Q$” is true when $P$ or $Q$ have different truth values
The proposition “$P$ if and only if $Q$” is true when $P$ or $Q$ have the same truth values
The proposition “$P$ if and only if $Q$” is true when $P$ and $Q$ have different truth values
The proposition “$P$ if and only if $Q$” is false when $P$ and $Q$ have different truth values.
solutionSteps: "if and only if" operation means that $P and $Q must have the same truth values.
Step 2: Proposition is false when $P$ and $Q$ have different truth values.
